It is right next to he Jiming Temple. You can visit the temple and climb up to the city wall where you will find beautiful scenery of the city s well as the lake that the walls are surrounding. This lake was the naval training center during the empire period.
Visited in November 2017, great to walk around, with great views of the city and river. Highly recommended if visiting Nanjing

There are ample spots around the city to visit the Nanjing City Walls. As we only wanted a whistle-stop tour of the wall we were advised to go to the part of the wall at Taiping Gate where the entrance fee also includes a visit to a small museum within the wall complex. The

It's easy to get to and the section we went to is right next to the Jiming Temple, in fact I believe you can access the wall from the temple by going over a small bridge. There was a small exhibit inside one of the guard houses explaining the history of the wall and with an
Lovely place to walk and see different parts of the city. We accessed it by the lake and then walked past a number of gates
Not far from the city center, and very convenient to visit. We were here last month, the autumn view was amazing.

The old city wall still exists only in sections, some much larger than others. The biggest section surrounds Xuanwuhu Park and requires a RMB30 fee to enter and climb. The wall is amazing, but there's really not much need to climb it or walk along the top as once you're there

We went on a Saturday and there was literally no one on the wall. It was a beautiful walk with some great views of the whole city. An excellent adventure. Also you can rent bikes if you don't want to walk. They even have a seat for a three year old to hang on to.
There are 2 entrance to the City Wall. If you want to see the whole of Nanjing, this is a great place to see it. Can walk on top of the wall to experience the ancient Nanjing
The city wall ptovides a great view on tge city. It's beautifully decorated with light. Night and day alike, Nanjing City Wall is always a good idea.
Not much to see, just a wall. It's kept up in good shape but what can you say about a wall? Lots of food and things around to pass the time and relax but a wall can only be so exciting?

Walking the Nanjing City Wall is wonderful - see the lake & the city on mostly flat surfaces. The climb up to the wall is steep stairs, but the wall itself is an easy walk. Take bottled water. You can walk several miles if you plan ahead. Strongly recommend this.
A great city to walk around and explore. And the wall is amazing and to think that it remains after all of these days and years is great. Great for a walk on a nice morning or afternoon.
Easy sightseeing , about one hour at slow pace. Educational exhibits in English. There is a fun shopping area just outside gate of City Wall, Hunan Lu.

If you like an ancient walls, you should see this one also. But behind the wall is large lake where you sit and rest, or rent some boats to go around the lake. There pedals or electric boats. You will have fantastic view from your boat over significant part of the city.
I went on a week day and had the wall almost all to myself. You can get a really nice view of the lake and the surrounding area, very beautiful and peaceful.

We saw the wall and gates at many places, but got onto the wall at the Timing Temple and walked east a long way. There is a good view of the lake below and the mountains with the tombs and memorials as well. Just thinking about the height and the breadth of the wall in its

. . . visit, even if you've visited other walls. Yes, it's similar, but it's also different, especially from northern cities. The bricks are not like many others. Walkway is narrower in many places. Access stairs around the wall are not like many others. You can tell it's
This city wall is amazing. You can see quite a bit views of lake near it. It's connected to a temple which is famous for its sakuras in the spring. It's a nice place for families to go.

Entrance fee: 50 yuan/person On the first floor, there are three tunnels with some short explanation in Chinese, English, Japanese, and sometimes Korean language. There is also archery if you want to try, price is 20 yuan and you get 8 arrows (if I'm not mistaken). Climbing to
Big Cty wall is impressing by its lenght and hight. We walked about 2 km admiring the magnificent view of Nanjing. At the end was a Temple with monastry. Awesome!
All this area in general is wonderful. Is a great place to visit, but you will need to do a little bit of walking to truly enjoy it.
Take a nice stroll along the wall that kept Nanjing safe. You can see the whole city and get some amazing pictures.

Similar to other city walls, but covering a very big area. The South Gate was interesting, but wall itself was just fine. Bike rentals weren't great. Compared to other city walls, like the one in Xi'An, it's nothing special.
boring. all walls are not created equal but they are all quite boring. definitely not a must see attraction while here

The wall is quite impressive for how long it is, size, and historical significance. At the China Gate there are golf cart rentals to ride along the wall. Other places it's nice to just walk along the wall and enjoy your day. Combine with visit to Xuanwu Lake to see both and have
We drove by it several times and it was cool all the time. There were engravings on the wall and it was so cool to see the history of this wonderful city!

Perhaps coming from the US, old things like this are particularly interesting. This wall was interesting but not as big as the city wall in Xian...and needless to say the Great Wall, but still interesting to look at and walk along. The most interesting part was a demonstration

When in Nanjing it is easy for you to combine a visit to the Nanjing City Wall and Xuanwu lake since the lake is next to the wall. The city wall is impressive and dates back to the Ming dynasty. Since Nanjing was the capital of the Ming it makes sense that a wall was built to

Cost 30RMB to climb the stairs to the wall. Those above get in at halh price...hehe, need proof of age. There's nothing special and unlike the Xi'an wall and Beijing wall, this has some sort of English transaltion describing when and how the wall was built.

The wall is great for a walk around the city. It's well kept and there are many different areas you can explore, e.g. walk next to the lake on the northern side or close to zhong hua men in the south. There's something for everyone.

Entered near museum just before December sunset. Light mist and cold, had it all to ourselves. Thousands of bricks have writing and makers mark still plainly visible from the 1360's. While lights on edges of crenellations and gates diffused in mist. 28 years to construct using

One of the few wall still largely intact in many places. We entered near the Zhongshan Gate and from there we had good views over the lake and surrounding area. The only downside now is that there is an entry fee, fewer access points to the wall, and limited entry times.

I think it's a great place to visit, first you can explore the Zhonghua Gate in Old town and the either take a walk along the wall or rent bike / golf car. Be prepared for a long way. And bring your water with you ) Entry fee is 50 yuan. Attraction opens at 10am and closes at

We took the south wall gate entrance and rented a golf cart type vehicle. That was so fun to stop to take pictures and hit the bumps. You get it for one hour so that was more than even time to do the whole wall where they allow the carts.

I spent the morning walking around the lake and then a good few hours exploring the wall, which was great. Even though its not as impressive as the Great Wall or Xian its still pretty cool and a great way to understand the history of Nanjing. Off you go then!
One of the many city walls around the Nanjing city. Take a 2-hour walk along the top of the walls for some good views of the Xuanwu lake.

Nanjing's city walls are certainly impressive. But I preferred the walls at for example Xi'an, as you can cycle at the top of them (whereas in Nanjing, you can just walk along the walls at the bottom). Still, there are quite a lot of footpaths along the bottom of the walls, so

I was taken to this place by the conference organizers. Its a beautiful place and you get one of the best views of the Nanjing city atop of this wall. It is rich in its heritage and gives a deep insight into the defenses of the Ming dynasty. The view especially of the sunset
The wall is great to look at and has a lot of history to it; unfortunately, a lot of the history you will have to find on your own. I do recommend seeing it and looking into the hostory
A formidable structure, left intact at least 700 years. Some 200-years old cannons on the top. Number of gates of different sizes.
i walked the wall from 4pm to sunset. It was wonderful - peaceful without the noise of the city and with few crowds but able to see all the city old and new. only cost 30rmb too - a bargain

There are several wall entrances within Nanjing and the one that appeared in the google map section can be accessed at the exit of Jiming Temple. Some of the walls can be accessed for free but most require a ticket to enter.

I went with a couple of friends onto the Nanjing city wall, the section near Zhonghuamen. There the walkable (or rideable, bike rental at the start) part is about 4km long. Very nice views of the city. While being on the wall notice the inscriptions on the stones, these are
Impressive wall which provides an opportunity to walk along sections an enjoy the contrasting views from each side. Take snacks and drinks to enjoy a few hours
Fun to walk on the wall and see how the town was protected. Views at all points were stunning. Walking the wall was difficult as it is uneven.
You should visit if you have a chance and be astonished by the amount of history within the district. And the temple is next to it, so it's a two in one visit.

This wall is more than 650 years, built (finished) in Ming Dynasty. The wall is still standing around Nanjing and the original bricks are covered with Chinese characters on one side, do you know why? It`s on the list of World Heritage, hope we can make it.
This place is good for picnic, gathering and also for a long walk in the evening along the lake. Lighting kites make sky more beautiful.

Extraordinary nice, with beautiful lake view (starting the walk from Jinming temple). An underrated piece of China. Rather than sharing one square meter with 1000 other people on the most busy pieces of the Great Wall, go here and enjoy a relaxing walk.
Check out the many bricks inscribed with the makers name and details, done as a form of quality control. It is a pity that some of the restorations done are bodges using the wrong materials.
Walking up and up and when you think you are at the destination a few more steps but well worth it The temple at the top is worth going up just for the view
The view from the city wall includes the tallest building in Nanjing & the ancient Buddhist nunnery- old meets new in China again. Fascinating!

There are some sections of the wall that are so quiet and peaceful, without any other tourists around, you'll forget you're in a modern tier 2 city! It reminds me of the city wall in Xi'an, except a lot more peaceful (and less wide).

It is an impressive place, the wall is tall and wide, very well built and and its conditions is just excellent. During day time is good to watch the extension, the weapons reproduction shown in there as well as the details of the construction, the signed bricks and impressive
One of the best attraction in Nanjing. It's a beautiful place to spend the day. The park is free but you have to pay 30 RMB to go to the wall.

There are many different places to get up on the Nanjing Wall. I like the nearest to Laomendong. Here, built into the wall are large rooms where soldiers were barracked. There are also some small historical exhibits which are interesting.
When you think of the invasions of Nanjing over the years the fact that this wall remains standing is truly amazing!

The old city wall offers great views (especially the section by the lake) and a good way of walking between sites such as the lake and the chicken temple. Beware that it offers no shade in Nanjing's very hot summers.
One of the many attractions in China with a great history. You may walk a few kilometers overviewing parts of the city.

The Nanjing city wall was the longest in the world when it was built (16th c). Long sections of it are still in existence. Visit the Zonghua Gate in the south for a great experience of the wall and its defensive role.
Beautiful, peaceful and historic entrance fee require in order to enter overlook breathtaking scenic of Xuan Wu Lake and Jiming Temple

We explored the wall in a couple of places and recommend: 1. Daytime - from the Jiming Temple with views of the XuanWu Lake and Park, Jiming Pagoda and Intercontinental hotel tower 2. Nighttime - from the Zhonghua Gate when the wall is nicely lit-up (come between 6.30-8pm) Each

The Nanjing City Wall has a few entrances but the main one is at Zhonghua Men. Needs to pay an entrance fee. The walk on top of the wall is quite breath taking as it will show you a different view of Nanjing. The walk can take at least 1.5h with some exit points along the way.

This was the first stop I made when I arrived in Nanjing on a bullet train from Shanghai. Not many taxi drivers spoke English in Nanjiang so I feverishly googled City Wall of Nanjing and several places popped up. One of them is on the outskirt of the city in a scenic area.

Very well maintained. As you would expect at a city wall, there are lots of steps, but they are even and of human size not like the Great Wall. Well worth the effort to climb and walk. Entry is reasonable and like most Chinese historic sites there are concessionary prices for

First time we went to the wall (around 2013), there were a couple of entrances you could go up the wall and some were free of charge. This time only one (proper/official) entrance was open and you had to pay the entrance fee. Just after the entrance you can read up about the
Great views of the city and nice to walk around. The Great Wall is not much wider but is more imposing because of its altitude. It is definitely a place where a sunhat is required on a hot day.

It's part of the city and you won't miss it. I suggest you to get onto the city wall via Zhong Hua Men before sunset and take a walk along the wall for 1 hour or so, I think it's the most beautiful scenery in Nanjing. Entrance fee is 50RMB from memory.

It was raining and cold for May in Nanjing, a walk from Zhonghua Gate to Wuding Gate is not enjoyable, but definitely memorable. Looking at the whole city rain, you look at the fragile and saddening history
Honestly it is quite a beautiful wall in between the park and the city. Definitely a must do if you go to Nanjing ! The ticket price is 30RMB if i remember correctly.
The ming wall offers a great view and offers a great history of this beautiful city .This is the longest city wall in the world,and there is plenty of space to move around.
nice wall in the middle of the city (longest city wall of the world) with an nice park and lake for lazy Sunday´s
Not really excitement for this place its just like a wall and u need to walk all the way middle of the city no really good natural effective not really clean.

It's not bad, but it's nothing special. It offers a chance to look at the city and park for a little higher up, and the exercise is good. But unless you know your Chinese history, it's just a walk on a stone wall. For me, the Great Wall of China is more impressive. On hot
City wall buily during the Ming dynasty. It is very impressive with large parts remaining or restored. The main gate is particularly impressive, exhibitions however a bit boring.
Other cities had their walls torn down in the rush to modernize, but for political reasons Nanjing was put last in line to receive modernization. Good thing!

It's a well preserved relic site from thousands years ago. I enter the site from Zhonghua Gate and walk along 3 km to the south. In the right side you can see the beautiful Qinhuai River where locals do their morning strolls, fishing and biking. More to the south you can catch a

I didn't get to walk on the wall as we visited rather late in the day. However we walked around part of the lake admiring the very impressive wall. Don't remember seeing too many other city walls that are as intact as this one. Very pleasant evening stroll along the lake,
I really enjoyed taking a walk on this ancient and giant wall. Also provides you with stunning views of the lake and city.
Ignore whoever said you can't walk on the wall. Yes you can. You pay ¥30, but you can. Amazing piece of history and views of the lake
Even though it was raining and foggy on the day we visited the city wall it was worth it. Quite impressive dimensions of height, depth, lenght...

Took the metro to Sanshan Street on line 1 and then walked down to the Gate of China. We spent some time here and then walked east for a good hour and a half until the wall ended at the water gate. Good opportunity to see parts of the city on both sides.

You can virtually feel the history of the Ming Wall by touching it and its amazing it stood the test of time despite the turbulence of mankind. The wall has outlived its purpose and now stand as a remembrance to the past that we should learn from. The only disappointment is that
Nanjing's history is one of protection of its people. The various sections of the Ming City Wall are important starting point of the tour.
Worth the climb up the stairs, a fun visit that is definitely worth revisiting with different lights and weather. Excellent for architecture and history buffs. And pretty cheap

I was in Nanjing China for an official visit. We took some time off one afternoon to pay a visit to the Nanjing City Wall and it was a worthwhile experience. I have not been to the Great Wall of China but the visit to the Nanjing City wall was itself an eye opener. To see the
The city wall provides good views but it is also difficult to leave, so make sure you use it as an itinerary item rather than a shortcut as you may get frustrated. Very limited entry and exit points
If you have time have a look at the wall and enjoy the view over the City. If you are lucky you will find bike rentals. We did it although it started to rain but we had a lot fun.

If you are in Nanjing you have to go to the wall. Not as long and impressive as Beijing but very well preserved and rebuilt. You can spend an hour walking at the top or even hire a bike and bike around. There is a very small museum and a small coffeshop. Unfortunately the view
Entrance fee RMB 30. 25km in total. A good place to see Ji Ming temple and xuanwu lake, especially for the sunset. Not so crowded. quiet and peaceful walk!
If you are in Nanjing you definitely want to spend few hours walking on the City Wall. It's a historical and cultural stroll, which I recommend to rent a bike if you want to visit it entirely.
Not much to look at but an interesting history. We drove around the city and had a review about the wall, etc.

The City Wall and the Scenic Place are actually one and the same. Whether you enter from up or down, the entry fee is 30 RMB. The Wall: The wall, designed by Emperor Zhu Yuanzhang after he founded the Ming Dynasty. Nanjing, the former capital over 600 years ago, the wall took

We took the subway to this site and walked about 1km. We took the bus back to the subway station. We ate along the way and there wasnt much food to eat there. The entrance fee was 30-50Y. Inside was pretty cool and we ended up staying in side the gate for a while and watched

This was an interesting history experience and had nice views along the way. Some steps, but not really strenuous. It did remind me of the Great Wall but much easier to do. It can be a long walk if you desire.
I walked along the wall in an afternoon and it was very pleasant. Could see the lake and had a great view of the city.
a must see while in town - visit the wall at the Gate of China. it gives you an idea of the great history of Nanjing

The architecture must be excellent considering the period. The engineering must be perfect to build such a wall. I was told repair and modernisation was done to the wall and I still the whole wall site is impressive. Next to the Great Wall of China, this mini version of wall

Very impressive site which we thoroughly enjoyed and spent a surprising large amount of time there. We loved the views from the top of the wall and wished we had walked a bit further on the wall but it was really great to see the sections we saw. If you have been to the Great

There are only a few 'types' of attraction in the world, whether they are museums, sky scrapers or monuments. The Nanjing City Wall is almost a type in itself. It is remarkable how well preserved it is and frankly how what an amazing achievement it is. A wall built brick
One of the highlights of Nanjing. A very well preserved medieval wall with nice views of the city. Do not recommend to walk the whole length on a sunny day.

Once up on the wall we had to walk some way before we could get back down at another gate. I know, I should have known better than to take a small child, but normally she's good at such things, but this particular place did not capture her imagination. It was a hot day and it

Truly amazing that such a large tall and long wall was constructed to surround the city. The work put into this and the effort to maintain and restore it is excellent. Well done to the people of Nanjing
A nice walk with a great view of the lakes and the city. A nice tea house and a museum to visit the wall.
A wall in near original condition. Don't wear your heals to this one ladies the floor is quite uneven. Great views, well worth a vist
This is a well preserved city wall from the Ming Dynasty. It stretches very long and is a great place for a stroll especially in spring or autumn.
It was incredible to walk on something as old as the city wall and look at the new city. The contrast is mind-blowing and I think you have to go.
If you are passing by, you might want to take a peek. But, it is not something you need to go out of your way to see.

Visited in November 2012, as usual city walls like this is very STRONG! A fortress type of wall that protects the city from wild invaders. Very similar to the Great Wall in Badaling or Mutianyu) Nice place to be)

I am very fond of historic wall in every old city. It is really amazing to walk on the top of this hundred years built city wall of this old city. Though it is narrower than the one in Xian, it is still an interesting and momorable experiencef for a complete walking. When you
I think it needs more middle-exit down the wall aheading to lake side.

Its the only wall built around the city in the world, its an amazing sites to be, just like the great wall of china in Beijing. You can walk up and around the wall on a pleasant evening, there are some nice food streets around the place that you may enjoy, If you are in Nanjing
True piece of history. Go in the direction of the Olympic rings and go to the top. It's scenic, there's a small museum, and you can see areas both inside and outside the Xuanwu Lake area.
Made forsafety of this ancient city, but now population and city limits exceeds much more outside wall. Still a landmark attraction for tourist. Well maintained wall.

The Ming City Wall is quite broad and large. It spans several dozen km and goes through many parts of the city you wouldn't get a great view of otherwise. You can walk as much or as little as you want as there are several exits, and the engrish signs all over the place really

The city wall is quite huge. I usually go up at the Xuanwumen side and walk until I get to Jiefangmen. That is usually a nice relaxing stroll that takes about 1 hour. But the whole wall is quite long and there are multiple access sites. From above you get great views of the

No need to risk your life crossing the busy streets, you cruise on a large elevated hiking trail, which is the 650 years old, one of the longest city walls in the world. You learn about the history of Nanjing on the way and discover the sweeping views of the city. Best urban

Yes, you're just walking on a wall...but I LOVED it! There was hardly anyone else up on the wall, the day was beautiful, and it was so peaceful to walk up there and look out over the beautiful Xuanwu park. I was able to go up for only 15 RMB because of the student discount. I

There are lots of places to get up on the wall most of them cost money. But the views are great. Make sure you have good shoes on and some water. There is not water to buy on most of the wall and if your older it will get very hot.

Seems silly when the actual attraction is the wall, which is better seen when you are not actually on it. If you are really interest in walking atop it, then you should visit another site that allows access to the wall - like Yuejiang temple - and kill two birds with one stone.

You see once of this many walls in other parts of China and you see all and unless you are into chinese history of the different dynasty, you may just not look in ewe. ..a good view once you are up ghe walls n try to imagine back then the life of soldiers n etc.mings dynasty has

There are 25km worth of walls that can be walked on. We paid 30 RMB (students were free) and walked from Xuan Wu Gate to the Jiming Temple (Olympic rings). It was worth it. If you could rent a bike and ride along that would be fun too. They have done a nice reconstruction
Its just a wall built by an emperor. A bit far from Zhonghuamen metro station. You won't find taxis easily. Entrance ticket is 50/person. 50%Discount for students. Only the view from the top is good.
The old town wall is very cool. The view is good and very cozy place.

The Nanjing City Wall is a fantastic sight to see and well worth the effort to visit if you find yourself in Nanjing. It is said to be the largest intact city wall in China. And honestly, I preferred it to the much more famous Great Wall outside Beijing. Perhaps because it
Great views, and some good walks along the top. Cant do the whole city but the sections you can do are really impressive and you see all sorts looking over the sides at the old cit

This is a superb example of a garrison fortification. Get down to the South Gate and start from here. There is a huge citadel with defences and battlements all around. The big thing here is that the bricks were made with inscriptions telling who paid or sponsored the brick,
like a younger small healthier version of the great wall but no tourist. lovely views around of city and lake area! easy to get around. some tower have informative history bits too

I love to get a perspective of a city from above if possible and from an ancient wall is even more special. Allow yourself some time to walk some of the many kilometers of wall that surround the city and sit adjacent to the lake and rivers. It is a great way to enjoy some
Nothing special......you can tell by the lack of Chinese tourists who usually are in great numbers at big attractions

Not sure if we come at the right spot, when we came around 5.30pm, the place was very quiet, and only less than 10 people, while the wall is amazing, and give you idea how they defended the city back then, nothing else special there. The wall open until 9pm (forgot what time it
This section is well preserved and gives an excellent insight into dynastic days of the glorious Ming. Best to visit at sunset to view the sky from in between the wall insets.
Not as big and long as great wall but a must to see when visiting nanjing. Main wall of the Ming dinasty which still stand to date.

Most of the city of Nanjing was destroyed in the 1930s during the massacre by the Japanese, and most of today's city is just concrete flats and high-rises, so to see something of the original city is welcome.

Easy to access and very well kept, spoilt in places by reproduction figures etc.However, take a close look at the actual bricks of the wall, each one signed by it's maker. Check the history before you go.
Despite the damage caused during the Japanese invasion of Nanjing, much of the walls are intact and very enjoyable to walk where you can.

Awesome City Wall ! Really impressive what people could build without a machines. Well maintained City Wall is very high and pretty wide on some places. You can view a modern city of NanJing with skyscrapers on the one side and the mountain above the lake on the another side of

It's a portion of a wall. What else can you say? It's fairly clean, it's been restored so it's not like you're looking at ancient ruins. Lots of foliage to see as you walk along, quite a few places to sit and rest. And it's free.

The wall is an important cultural relic for the inscriptions on the bricks. The Nanjing citizens attach great importance to the work of protecting the wall and access to climb onto the wall is limited.

Awesome place. Wear comfy shoes and clothes, bring an umbrella for rain and sun, and a poncho. It rained in the middle of the day. You will go up the mountain with a ski lift chair. Coming down, you have an option of ski lift or a wagon!!!!

I went to the Shanghai railway station and found the English window (49). A colleague already printed out the train schedule for the day of all Gtrains to Nanjing so I circled the train I wanted and handed it to the agent. She indicated there were no 2nd class seats on that

Absolutely include this on your itinerary as it provides a fabulous perspective of fortifications - and the need for same - in centuries past. The length and complexity of the wall when it was constructed is quite extraordinary and you can certainly feel the history as you walk

I had other plans for the day but somehow ended walking this wall and was very impressed without knowing at the time any of the history of the wall. You get great views to Xuanwuhu Lake and park below, the Purple Mountain district and the city. I walked this wall and continued

A great story behind this wall with a great view from the top to the outer areas of the city. Back in the day you would have had to crazy to try and penetrate all four gates to get through the city wall! If the archers didn't get you the soldiers running out of the hidden dens

I couldn't help thinking, as we approached Nanjing, of the sorrowful history of the massacre in 1937, I thought the city would still have a pall hanging over it but not at all. It is a thriving, happy bustling place, situated at the foot of a mountain but very flat in itself

This wall is placed between jiming temple and xuanwu lake.. i don't really have a plan to went here but since i have to cross it so it doesn't hurt to take a look.. the wall was really big and long, it reminds me of great wall only this one located in the middle of the city..
The wall is pretty impressive even as Nanjing is modernizing itself. It's a landmark to add to set Nanjing apart from other cities in China.

This one impressive wall. One of only three large city walls left in China. It even manages to outshine the Xian city wall not only in length but also in sheer audacity. It was built around 1370 and is 33 km long. I'm not sure if its complete as I only saw sections of it.

The wall is magnificent and beautiful, a must see if you're in Nanjing. You can actually catch glimpses of it as you are traveling on the road, but standing on top of it is just different. There's no shop or activities here, just walking and admiring the views and materiality of
An interesting relic is what I would categorize this attraction. I did make it a point to travel here to visit, and enjoy the park with my guitar a couple of hours before leaving for Shanghai.

Walked the section along Xuanwu Lake. It's quiet on the wall, with views of Xuanwu Lake & the city. The wall is well preserved and feels quite imposing in some parts. Hard to believe they are hundreds of years old. Saw a couple of exhibits along the walk but they were only in
Like a mini great wall. Very quiet and nice views. Go to the one connected to the temple also so you can knock out 2 in one.

Had a great trip out to the Nanjing wall - very interesting and you can explore lots of the nooks etc - Make sure you feel the bricks inside the tunnels for hiding the soldiers in (they are warm in winter!) Well worth a trip out!

This may be a false impression, but I felt the city wall was respected, not artificially preserved but allowed to stand with its own presence a reminder of power through the ages. The wall is huge, part of the modern landscape (with children playing on the top, in care of

Have walked the entire walk a number of times with members of the Hopkins-Nanjing Center community. Delightful group outing. Entire walk takes anywhere from 6-10 hours, with lunch and other breaks. Some fantastic parts; some, not so.

We walked from the lake to the wall and paid our 30RMB for the two of us to go onto it! not sure what that meant. Walked along the wall for about a mile, great views over the lake and parts of the city, on public holiday it was busy but not crowded busy like the rest of Nanjing

The City Wall is of the ancient times that still stands till today. There are so much of additional items added where it is mixed with the contemporary. Having aid that, it is still a tourist attraction, and locals come here everyday to walk around, exercise. If you are a fan
If you had a bicycle ride on the Xian wall - you'd better not to go there. Most of pieces are still under reconstruction, the reconstructed parts though are a bit far from perfect also.
You need to take a small stroll on these walls as they give you a complete different view of the city of Nanjing. See temples and lakes from a (low flying) bird eye view.
..... and it's in amazingly good condition. It extends a very great distance and speaks of the deep history of this extraordinary city.
Like other cities Nanjing has its own wall in which from different parts of the city you can get access and depending on the side you get in you can have nice view of the city.
On a sunny day it was pleasant to chill out by the walls and the moat. Very picturesque but if it was in another city it wouldn't be notable.

The city wall is totally reconstructed and you can not walk along most of it - only climb to the top of one of the gate towers and look around. A couple of interesting exhibits are found within the caves of the wall. Overall, this is worth maximum an hour of your time.

How did they built this magnificent structure. Walk along it and imagine what is is like hundreds of years ago. Strong winds to be expected if you go during the cooler months. Bring along warm clothing a.

The wall can be visited in several different areas. In many ways it is like many of the other city walls that can be visited in China. This one gives yo a nice view because the wall is quite tall. We were here at dusk so they started closing parts of the wall. It was this

Walked over to this from the Nanjing Intercontinental when a meeting finished early. It's an easy walk, straight down Beijing Street from the roundabout and the to the left when you see the big yellow temple. The Temple is beautiful, too! But don't miss out on the wall. Walk

Built by the first Ming emperor 600 years ago at great expense with 200,000 laborers over 21 years, this city wall is truly magnificant and is one of the best preserved in China. The wall is beautiful by itself, but unfortunately it is currently adorned by ostentatious,
Enjoy a nice stroll on the wall and visit the museum to understand this incredible structure. You can walk down to the lake and enjoy Te peach blossoms this time of the year!
Take the time to see this wall if you can. Sure it's not the Great Wall, but it's less crowded and still very impressive. Note: it maybe quite difficult to get a taxi from this area.

The wall at Nanjing is one of the best examples of a Chinese city wall. The intact and restroed sections are very impressive and much taller than many walls in China. The section at Jiming temple is probably the best.
Nanjing's city wall is very well conservated and still exist in most if not all places. Worth a look at when you visit Nanjing...
Impressive achievement but under utilized for tourism purposes, most of the wall is inaccessible. Size is more impressive than Xian, but access is not.
Although the wall is just that, a huge brick wall...it is well-built and looks like it would protect to the people. It is next to a park and you can hit golf balls into the lake there.
To be honest, there's not much to see - and it's a fair way out. But it's a piece of history, most interesting for its connection to the Nanjing massacre.
A very nice historical place to visit. It looks that it was massively renovated (?) but it will still be worthwhile to explore. Take few pictures of the river from the top of the wall

If I'm honest I found the site a little below my expectations. Interesting only for an hour or two at most with only access allowed to a small part of the site. Unless it was part of an organised tour I wouldn't go out my way o visit
The architecture with it 5 layers of walls is impressive. We wre part of a tour but if we'd have been given more time we would have cycled around the walls as you can loan bikes

Worth a quick trip to the south of the city but only to witness the scale of the engineering. The wall has been skillfully and tastefully restored but they really need some information about its history.
I love the walls - all the different aspects. They can be be walked on many parts. My favorite walk is for Taipingmen gate, along the Xuanwo lake edge and down again at the monastery.
i heard this websit just now from a foreigner friend named mira. she has a italia restrant. she is very fine, and i trust her. so i come here

Nanjing City Wall is another underappreciated historic site in China, the wall is not as large or well restored as Xian's but is well worth the time. It provides good views of the city- including the contrasts of modern skyscrapers and ancient pagodas- and is easy to reach

This wall runs near the temple to near purple mountain on the other side. Both sides have entrances and exits. There is a small cost to get up on the wall but it is worth it. Its a nice walk if you are heading to purple mountain from the west near the temples. It offers mainly

We walked the wall on a couple of occasions and did find interesting. Their is a small cost to entering the facility, but you should attempt to walk here during a cooler time of the day. It is amasing to think back in time and consider how the wall was constructed so many years

While Nanjing has grown beyond it's ancient wall, the structure remains Larger than Life as sections still stand tall over neighborhoods. Whether it snakes along the rivers or rambles through the shadow of skyscrapers the wall offers views and history that is literally Solid as

The site includes a museum embedded in the wall as well as miles of walks on and along the wall. The views are spectacular. My only complaint is that the museum (quite extensive) does not have anything in English. Too bad - you could really spend an hour or two just in the
These walls need to be seen to be appreciated. There are several stopp off points to walk sections of them, and it is well worth the hour or so to appreciate their size.

From what I've read, it's still the most complete ancient wall in china or the world today that is still standing strong. http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5324/ An excellent view from the top, it has 4 gates: Xuanwu, Yifeng, Yijiang, Donghua. The main gate is at

Interesting and teaming with history. Kids loved the bike ride on top of the wall and also the musical stairs. Try not to go in the heat of the day, the glare and heat on top of the wall is severe. Take hats and lots of water.
Worthwhile visit - take your walking shoes for a hike through a pretty garden to the tower that overlooks the old city walls. Great view of the city.
I visit two parts of Nanjing City Wall - the northen part with view on Xuanavu lake was amazing, southern part (near Zhonguamen) was quite boring.
I would recondment visitor to plan their trip there in CNY period, lots of lanterns there as we stroll along the wall in the evening.

The walls of Nanjing define the city as well as nearly completely encircle it. There are great views of the wall from many places, but you definitely get a better perspective by walking on it. There are good exhibits and good English explanations of various parts of the wall.
well at least more authentic - worth walking along the 3k or so by Xunwa lakes and then taking a cab to the south gate which is really a bank of four gates which is in excellent condition.
From this wall, you can really see the past, in the form of the Buddhist Tempe, and the present, in the form of tall, modern skyscrapers. The contrast is breathtaking.
So disappointing. The wall is not preserved from littering, dirt and dog poo. They should learn from Xi'An. If you want to see a nice city wall - head to Xi'An or Beijing.

This is a must see during a Nanjing visit, incredible construction built around 1400 a.c. this massive 33 km long wall around the city. Big entrances at several sides of the city were massive defensive outposts. Great work with interesting quality management (stones from

The walk on the ancient city walls of Nanjing will take no more than an hour, but the views from this ancient walls are stunning. Whether you choose to look at the city, or prefer the stunning scenary of Xuanwu lake, it's worth the 10RMB entrance fee.
This was worth a stop on the tour. Not a long stop but good to see.
Takes an hour or so but we really liked it. Don't miss it
Not really much to see after the first view, but you can walk for as long as you like just taking in the enormity of them. Around the lake the views are better.

It's amazing to walk along such magnificent structures and the view is one to NOT be missed! I enjoyed walking along the wall and later along the lake and to the center islands. Make sure you have a good portion of the day set aside for the Jiming Temple, the Nanjing City wall

On the first day we did a walk on the Wall, that is world heritage site. Nobody was on the Wall, so we had an undisturbed walk. At the end of the wall it turned out the gate is closed and we had to walk back to the original place. It was made from granite. We began at Gate of
It costs RMB 15 to walk on the top of the city wall from one side to the rather, money well spent as the view is very lovely, especially if the weather is fine.
Be prepared for a long walk. Parts open to the public extend for miles and provide pleasant and varying vistas of the city. Do not go if it will rain as there is no shelter from a downpour.

We were sorry that we did not have more time to spend on the wall. One can rent bikes and go for a bumpy spin, however, just waking along on the top was great as well. The wall is an amazing structure.

During my two days I visited the city wall from two access points: Zhonghua Gate and Jiming Temple. The former provides entrance on the southern section of the wall and has the added bonus of being able to rent a bike for a small fee if you are interested. There are decent
Check out the "signed" bricks. Apparently, if a brick failed, the maker and his supervisor were held accountable and executed!

I liked the Nanjing City Wall. It was pretty cool but not overly special. You could probably have a good time having a picnic up there, and we saw a couple brides getting pictures. The view is much more impressive than Xi'an's city wall. We were just south of the lake. We got to
Worth a look for historical value. Great to just take a walk along the wall at XuanWu Men area because of the natural surroundings.

The Ming City Wall was actually a long 33km wall that protected the city of Nanjing since the Ming dynasty. It was very impressive then for its engineering and even thought to be best in the world during that age. Today, there is no one place that is exclusively the "Ming City

The Ming Palace (Chinese: 明故宫; pinyin: Míng Gùgōng; lit.: 'Ming Former Palace'), also known as the "Forbidden City of Nanjing", was the 14th-century imperial palace of the early Ming dynasty, when Nanjing was the capital of China.


== History ==


=== 14th century ===
Zhu Yuanzhang, who became the founder and first Emperor of the Ming dynasty, began building a palace in what was then known as Jiankang in 1367. At the time, he was self-styled "King of Wu". The palace was built outside the existing city of Jiankang, and was completed by 1368. With its completion, Zhu proclaimed the Ming Dynasty; with himself as the first emperor, known as the Hongwu Emperor; and that Jiankang, now Yingtian, was the "southern capital" ("nanjing") of his empire. For the next few years, few changes were made to the palace in Nanjing as the Emperor focused on building the "middle capital", located in his home town of Fengyang.
In 1373 the Hongwu Emperor shifted his focus back to Nanjing, with a substantial program of expansion and refurbishment of the palace which was completed in 1375. Further expansion occurred in 1392. In 1398 the Hongwu Emperor died, and was succeeded by his grandson, the Jianwen Emperor. A civil war soon ensued as Zhu Di, son of the Hongwu Emperor and uncle of the Jianwen Emperor, sought to take the crown from his nephew.


=== 15th—18th centuries ===
In 1402, Zhu Di took Nanjing and ascended the throne as the Yongle Emperor. The Jianwen Emperor disappeared amid a fire at the imperial Ming Palace.
The Yongle Emperor was keen to return to Beiping (now Beijing), where he was enfeoffed as a prince. To accomplish this, he raised Beiping to the status of a second capital, adding a Jing suffix to its name - Beiping therefore became the "northern capital", Beijing. Zhu Di began building a palace in Beijing. The Nanjing palace lost its position as the emperor's main residence to Beijing's Forbidden City in 1420 when the Yongle Emperor officially relocated the imperial capital to Beijing. Nanjing retained the status of the "reserve" capital throughout the almost three centuries of the Ming era, with its own "reserve" court and "reserve" ministries, and the palace was placed in the care of officials of the Imperial Household Department. However, the palace was afflicted with a series of fires, which caused damages that were, for the most part, not repaired. In 1449, the three main halls of the Outer Court (the ceremonial seat of government) burned down and were never rebuilt. Other fires destroyed other parts of the palace.
After the fall of Beijing to Li Zicheng's rebels (and, soon thereafter, to the Qing dynasty) in 1644, the Nanjing Ming Palace briefly became the seat of the Prince of Fu, who was crowned the "Hongguang Emperor" in Nanjing in an attempt to continue the Ming dynasty (one of a series of short-lived regimes known collectively as the Southern Ming dynasty). By this time only a small portion of the palace was intact, and the Hongguang Emperor set about rebuilding some sections of the palace.
However, the following year (1645) the Qing armies reached Nanjing. The Hongguang Emperor fled and officials of the "reserve" court surrendered. Under the Qing dynasty, the former imperial sector of Nanjing was garrisoned by the Manchu armies of the Eight Banners, with the palace itself becoming the yamen of two military commands. Throughout the Qing dynasty, the Ming palace was gradually demolished, with stone and carvings taken away to be used as building material and decorative elements on other projects.
By the time of the Kangxi Emperor and the Qianlong Emperor's tours of Nanjing in the 17th and 18th centuries, the Ming palace was already in ruin, and the two emperors both stayed elsewhere in the city.


=== 19th century ===
When the Taiping Revolution leaders declared Nanjing to be the capital of their Taiping Heavenly Kingdom, they chose not to restore the Ming Palace, but to build a new Palace of the Heavenly King. In this process, they sourced a large amount of construction material from the remains of the Ming Palace, until almost nothing remained of the buildings and walls. When the Taiping Revolution was defeated, the Qing troops razed the new palace in 1864, and built new traditional-style government buildings on that site.


=== 20th century ===
The Republic of China (1912-49) established Nanjing as its capital in 1928, and transformed one of the Qing buildings into the Presidential Palace. The planned development of the capital called for a new central executive zone to be built, around the Presidential Palace, on the former Ming Palace complex grounds. The plan was never completed. In 1929, a major road, present day East Zhongshan Road, was built in an east-west direction across the palace complex site, dividing it into northern and a southern portions.
In the 1930s, a series of buildings were built in and around the northern portion of the palace complex site, including the offices of two Kuomintang party organs, in a "neo-classical" style referencing traditional palace architecture, placed symmetrically near the old east and west palace gates. The National Central Museum, the present day Nanjing Museum building, was also built in the northern section. The southern portion became a small airstrip. The building of the airstrip resulted in the demolition of the two protruding arms of the Meridian Gate, the impressive former front gate of the Ming Palace complex.


== The Ming Palace today ==
No building within the palace survives today. Among other structures, the gate platforms of the Meridian Gate (the southern, front gate of the palace), Donghua Gate (the Gate of Eastern Glory, the eastern gate of the palace), and the Xi'an Gate (the Gate of Western Peace, the western outer gate of the palace) survive, though none of the wooden gatehouses survive, and the protruding wings of the Meridian Gate have been demolished. The inner and outer bridges of the Golden Water, which lie on the main north-south axis just inside and just outside the front gate respectively, survive. A number of isolated column elements and stone carvings also survive, and a number of foundations have been excavated.
The site of the three halls of the Outer Court has been established as a commemorative park, while the area around the Meridian Gate is also a park. Many of the remaining stone carvings and architectural components of the palace have been moved to the latter park and are arranged for display.
Large parts of the former palace are now occupied by various agencies and organisations such as the Aeronautical and Aerospace University of Nanjing, the Archives of the Nanjing Military District, and the No. 2 Historical Archives of China.


== Transportation ==
The palace is accessible from Minggugong Station of Nanjing Metro.

text.wiki:
Nanjing Municipal Museum (Chinese: 南京市博物館; pinyin: Nánjīng shì Bówùguǎn), the city museum of Nanjing, is a comprehensive museum of history and art, located inside Chaotian Palace. The museum was formally established in 1978 and is a key historical and cultural site.
With rich and exquisite cultural relics, the museum holds exhibitions such as “Treasures in Nanjing Municipal Museum”, “the Feature of the Six Dynasties”, “Nanjing: The Capital of Ming Dynasty ”, “Nanjing: A Home for Royalty”, “Seven Overseas Voyages by Zheng He”, “Archaeological Achievements in Ten Years ”, etc.


== See also ==
Nanjing Museum
List of museums in China


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website (in Chinese)

text.wiki:
Qixia Mountain (simplified Chinese: 栖霞山; traditional Chinese: 棲霞山; pinyin: Qīxiá shān) is a mountain in the northeast part of Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China.In the Southern Dynasties (420–589), there was a Qixia cottage (栖霞精舍) in the mountain, so the mountain's name Qixia derived from it. Qixia Mountain includes mountain peaks: the main peak, Sanmao Peak, with an elevation of 286 m (938 ft); Dragon Mountain, like a lying dragon, located in northeast; Tiger Mountain, like a fallen tiger, located in the northwest. Qixia Mountain has many scenic spots and historical sites. Its red autumnal leaves and especially its Dongfeitian grottos which were founded in 2000, make it a famous tourist attraction both at home and to abroad.

text.wiki:
The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing, part of the former Great Bao'en Temple, is a historical site located on the south bank of external Qinhuai River in Nanjing, China. It was a pagoda constructed in the 15th century during the Ming dynasty, but was mostly destroyed in the 19th century during the course  of the Taiping Rebellion. A modern life size replica of it now exists in Nanjing.In 2010 Wang Jianlin, a Chinese businessman, donated a billion yuan (US$156 million) to the city of Nanjing for its reconstruction. This is reported to be the largest single personal donation ever made in China. In December 2015, the modern replica and surrounding park opened to the public.


== History ==

The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing was designed during the reign of the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402–1424), shortly after its construction in the early 15th century. It was first discovered by the Western world when European travelers like Johan Nieuhof visited it, sometimes listing it as one of the Seven Wonders of the World. After this exposure to the outside world, the tower was seen as a national treasure to both locals and other cultures around the world.
On 25 March 1428, the Xuande Emperor ordered Zheng He and others to take over the supervision for the rebuilding and repair of the Great Bao'en Temple at Nanjing. He completed the construction of the temple in 1431.In 1801, the tower was struck by lightning and the top four stories were knocked off, but it was soon restored. The 1843 book, The Closing Events of the Campaign in China by Granville Gower Loch, contains a detailed description of the tower as it existed in the early 1840s. In the 1850s, the area surrounding the tower erupted in civil war as the Taiping Rebellion reached Nanjing and the rebels took over the city. They smashed the Buddhist images and destroyed the inner staircase to deny the Qing enemy an observation platform. American sailors reached the city in May 1854 and visited the hollowed tower. In 1856, the Taiping destroyed the tower either in order to prevent a hostile faction from using it to observe and shell the city or from superstitious fear of its geomantic properties. After this, the tower's remnants were salvaged for use in other buildings, while the site lay dormant until a recent surge to try to rebuild the landmark.


== Description ==

The tower was octagonal with a base of about 97 feet (30 m) in diameter. When it was built, the tower was one of the largest buildings in China, rising up to a height of 260 feet (79 m) with nine stories and a staircase in the middle of the pagoda, which spiraled upwards for 184 steps. The top of the roof was marked by a golden pineapple. There were original plans to add more stories, according to an American missionary who in 1852 visited Nanjing. There are only a few Chinese pagodas that surpass its height, such as the still existent 275-foot-tall (84 m) 11th-century Liaodi Pagoda in Hebei or the no longer existent 330-foot-tall (100 m) 7th-century wooden pagoda of Chang'an.
The tower was built with white porcelain bricks that were said to reflect the sun's rays during the day, and at night as many as 140 lamps were hung from the building to illuminate the tower. Glazes and stoneware were worked into the porcelain and created a mixture of green, yellow, brown and white designs on the sides of the tower, including animals, flowers and landscapes. The tower was also decorated with numerous Buddhist images.

text.wiki:
Purple Mountain or Zijin Shan (Chinese: 紫金山; pinyin: Zĭjīn Shān; lit.: 'Purple-Gold Mountain') is located on the eastern side of Nanjing in Jiangsu province, China. It is 448.2 m (1467 ft) high. Its peaks are often found enveloped in purple and golden clouds at dawn and dusk, hence its name.
A small mountain with an area of about 20 square kilometers (4,900 acres), Purple Mountain is a mountain related to many historical events of both ancient and modern China. It was originally known as Bell Mountain (traditional Chinese: 鐘山; simplified Chinese: 钟山; pinyin: Zhōngshān) and also became known as Mount Jiang (traditional Chinese: 蔣山; simplified Chinese: 蒋山; pinyin: Jiǎngshān) after Sun Quan named Jiang Ziwen, an Eastern Han official whose spirit was said to haunt the site, as the mountain's god during the Three Kingdoms era. The name Zijin (紫金) means "copper" - when copper is pure, it appears purple in color, so in Chinese, it is also called purple-gold. It is also named Mount Jinling (金陵山), due to its purple rocks. Jinling means "the mount of purple-gold". It is the origin of the nickname "Jinling" (金陵) of Nanjing. During the Ming dynasty, it was also called Mount Shenlie (神烈山).
More than 200 heritage and scenic tourist sites are now located in or around the mountain, including three national historical sites, nine provincial historical sites, and 33 prefectural historical sites. Located in or close to the hillside of the mountain, there are also about a dozen national research institutes and universities. The Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum, the tomb of Sun Yat-sen, is located at the foot of the mountain.
Purple Mountain has 621 species of vascular plants, from 383 genera, 118 families (including 78 cultivated species).
